SENT.plain: Case report concerning a three years old boy with benign intracranial hypertension
The typical symptoms are results of increased intracranial pressure, associated with headache, vomiting, choked disk, occasionally dehiscence of cranial sutures and sixth nerve paresis
In computed tomography there were no tumor signs
In childhood a possible cause in thrombosis of the lateral sinus following an occult mastoiditis after antibiotic therapy
Mastoidectomy, intensive antibiotic therapy as well as serial lumbar punctures led to complete recovery in most cases
